title: James de Rothschild (politician)
text:
James Armand Edmond de Rothschild <a href="Distinguished%20Conduct%20Medal">DCM</a> <a href="Deputy%20lieutenant">DL</a> (1 December 1878 – 7 May 1957), sometimes known as Jimmy de Rothschild, was a British <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> politician and philanthropist, from the wealthy <a href="Rothschild%20family">Rothschild</a> international banking dynasty.
Biography.
De Rothschild was the son of <a href="Edmond%20James%20de%20Rothschild">Edmond James de Rothschild</a> of the French branch of family. He was educated at <a href="Lyc%C3%A9e%20Louis-le-Grand">Lycée Louis-le-Grand</a> in Paris and at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>. He served in the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>, at the outset as an enlisted man in the French Army then as an officer in <a href="The%20Royal%20Canadian%20Dragoons">The Royal Canadian Dragoons</a>, and ended the war as an officer in the British Army, serving in <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a> as a <a href="major">major</a> in the 39th Battalion, The <a href="Royal%20Fusiliers">Royal Fusiliers</a> (part of the "<a href="Jewish%20Legion">Jewish Legion</a>"). He was awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Conduct%20Medal">Distinguished Conduct Medal</a>.
He was a keen follower of the <a href="Horse%20racing">turf</a> and a racehorse owner. His 33-1 runner "Bomba" won the <a href="Ascot%20Gold%20Cup">Ascot Gold Cup</a> in 1909.
He married <a href="Dorothy%20de%20Rothschild">Dorothy Mathilde Pinto</a> in 1913. She was 17 years old; he was 35.
He became a naturalised Briton in 1920, and in 1922 he inherited from <a href="Alice%20Charlotte%20von%20Rothschild">Alice de Rothschild</a> the <a href="Waddesdon%20Manor">Waddesdon Manor</a> estate of his great-uncle <a href="Baron%20Ferdinand%20de%20Rothschild">Baron Ferdinand de Rothschild</a>, the Liberal <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) for <a href="Aylesbury%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Aylesbury</a> from 1885 to 1898.
Politics.
Described by the "Journal of Liberal History" as "one of the Liberal Party's most colourful MPs", Rothschild served as <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> for the <a href="Isle%20of%20Ely%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Isle of Ely</a> constituency from 1929 to 1945.
His defeat by <a href="Harry%20Legge-Bourke">Harry Legge-Bourke</a> in the <a href="1945%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">1945 general election</a> was one of only a few gains by the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative Party</a> that year, with his Liberal colleagues <a href="Archibald%20Sinclair">Archibald Sinclair</a> and <a href="William%20Beveridge">William Beveridge</a> similarly losing to Tory opponents.
During the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a> he was Parliamentary Secretary to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Supply">Ministry of Supply</a> in the <a href="Coalition%20Government%201940-1945">Coalition Government 1940-1945</a>. He was also a <a href="deputy%20lieutenant">deputy lieutenant</a> for the <a href="county%20of%20London">county of London</a> and a <a href="justice%20of%20the%20peace">justice of the peace</a> in <a href="Buckinghamshire">Buckinghamshire</a>.
Philanthropy.
Rothschild continued to support his father's <a href="Zionism">Zionist</a> causes, and donated 6,000,000 <a href="Israeli%20Pound">Israeli Pound</a>s towards the construction of the <a href="Knesset">Knesset</a> building in <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, which was completed in 1966.
When he died in 1957, he bequeathed Waddesdon Manor to the <a href="National%20Trust%20for%20Places%20of%20Historic%20Interest%20or%20Natural%20Beauty">National Trust</a>. His widow <a href="Dorothy%20de%20Rothschild">Dorothy de Rothschild</a> inherited the surrounding estate, and maintained a strong interest in the house and collections until she died in 1988.
